content.description: The crack starts with a bouldery thin finger crack that quickly leads to a bomber lieback/slab.  Two small roofs are passed and all too quickly you are scrambling to the top.  Two mussy hook anchors sit above the ledge.  Still plenty of sand up there.
content.protection: Small nuts to start, cams to 2 inches.  Mussy hook anchors.
content.location: This is the obvious crack on the left side of the wall.  A large block sits at the base and makes a nice spot to rack up on.  Just don't think too much about where it came from.

content.description: Start off the block next to the roof.  Climb a series of good holds to the crux half way up.  Technical feet on crumbling holds yields a balancy clip.  Hang on for the next two bolts and it done.  Good movement.  Better than it looks.
content.location: Located on the right side of the wall.  Starts off the block at the left side of the roof.

content.description: Thin climbing leads to a high first bolt.  This is followed by an undercling and long moves to a blank shallow dihedral with poor feet.  Two bolts lead to a jug and the top.  This could be a great route if all the holds don't break off.  And yes, the mono is all natural.
content.location: This is the center line on this wall.  Just right of the Sandy Cooter.
